newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Now it can be told--London rule pleased many in HK.
newsitem.headline: Now it can be told--London rule pleased many in HK.

text.p: Hong Kong people are generally satisfied with British rule which ends at midnight June 30 when London hands the territory back to Beijing, a current survey says.

The poll, by the Social Sciences Research Centre at the University of Hong Kong, found 63.7 percent of respondents were "quite satisfied" with British rule, the centre said in a statement on Saturday.
The study, which polled 548 people on June 25 via telephone, found 7.2 percent were not satisfied and 13.5 percent neutral.
Some 64.5 percent also said the British government had accrued more merits than faults in the development of Hong Kong, while only 2.9 percent said it had accrued more faults.
Some 21.3 percent also said Governor Chris Patten had accrued more merit than faults during his five-year term while 18.9 percent said Patten had accrued more faults.
